data.name: Census Tracts, Boston (GEOID10: State+County+Tract)
data.abstract:
As of the 2010 census, Boston, MA contains 7,288 city blocks, defined as any piece of land bounded by streets or water on all sides, and not divided by any streets or water. These are nested in 558 block groups, which are themselves nested in 178 census tracts. Census geographies are a natural hierarchy, with the unique identifier at each level being an extension of the level above it, indicating the specific region and all of the higher-order regions that contain it.

Census variables are split into two categories: identifying characteristics and geographic information. Variables are consistent across all three census levels, though some variables appear in one file and not in others. Identifying characteristics includes variables regarding the basic identity and attributes of the block. Geographic information provides further detail on the location of the block and the other geographies that contain it. Nesting started with the block level, because all geographies, census or otherwise, conform to block boundaries. Linking to non-census geographies was done by identifying the location of the centroid of each block.

Because block groups and tracts do not nest perfectly within non-census geographies, this linking was done by identifying the region that contained the plurality of the block group or tract’s land area. Some non-census geographies crossed over census the boundaries of a particular level too often, however, to make such linkages reliable, and thus were omitted: for block groups, Precincts were not linked; for tracts, Precincts, Neighborhood Statistical Areas, and ZIP Codes were not linked.

Note: Although this data is in the 2015 BARI Geographical Infrastructure dataverse, the data is from the 2010 Census. However, between years BARI may fill in missing information within the Census files, so it is still best to use the Census files from the latest Geographical Infrastructure Dataverse. This data set includes a series of census indicators for tracts. These are not listed and described in the current version of the documentation, however.

Provided by the Boston Area Research Initiative (BARI): https://www.northeastern.edu/csshresearch/bostonarearesearchinitiative/

This file, along with other administrative geographies utilized by the City of Boston, may be found in the Dataverse repository:

  • Data: http://dx.doi.org/10.7910/DVN/QDRUAZ
  • Documentation: http://dx.doi.org/10.7910/DVN/C5IULB
data.title: Census Tracts 2010, Boston (BARI)

expected_format.description:
Concatenation of state, county and tract for 2010 Census Tracts.  Reference: https://www.census.gov/geo/maps-data/data/tract_rel_layout.html

Note:  Across the US, this can be a zero-padded "string" but the original Boston layer has this column as "numeric"
expected_format.name: 2010 Census Boston GEOID10 (State+County+Tract)

data.name: Addresses, Boston
data.abstract:
Unique addresses present in the parcels data set, which itself is derived from the City of Boston’s Master Address List. It was constructed as the list of all unique combinations of address, zip, and X and Y in the parcels data set. It contains 118,918 addresses, each containing one or more parcels. Provided by the Boston Area Research Initiative (BARI)

https://www.northeastern.edu/csshresearch/bostonarearesearchinitiative/

For more information on this dataset, please refer to "A Guide to Using the Geographical Infrastructure of Boston (2015)":

http://dx.doi.org/10.7910/DVN/C5IULB
data.title: Addresses 2015, Boston (BARI)

expected_format.description: Boston, Administrative Geography, Boston Address Location ID.  Example: 1, 2, 3...nearly 120000
expected_format.name: Boston Address Location ID (integer)

data.title: BRA Neighborhood Statistical Areas 2015, Boston (BARI)

expected_format.description: Boston, Administrative Geography, Boston BRA Neighborhood Statistical Area ID (integer).  Examples: 1, 2, 3, ... 68, 69
expected_format.name: Boston BRA Neighborhood Statistical Area ID (integer)

data.title: Census Blocks 2015, Boston (BARI)

expected_format.description:
15-character code that is the concatenation of fields consisting of the following:
  • 2-character state FIPS code
  • 3-character county FIPS code
  • 6-character census tract code
  • 4-character tabulation block code
reference: https://www.census.gov/geo/maps-data/data/baf_description.html
expected_format.name: 2010 Census Block (15-digit block id)

data.name: Intersections (Census), Boston
data.abstract:
Intersections comprise two data sets. One is a catalog of all intersections generated by the Census TIGER line roads data from 2013. The other is a master list of intersections maintained by the City of Boston that has then been merged with Census geographies (to the same intersection name when possible, otherwise to the closest point). This dataset is the former: the census data.

Variables are largely equivalent between the two files. The two data sets can be connected via their unique identifiers. They are split into two categories: identifying characteristics and geographic information. Identifying characteristics includes variables regarding the basic identity and attributes of the intersection. Geographic information provides further detail on the location of the intersection and the other geographies that contain it.

Provided by the Boston Area Research Initiative (BARI)

https://www.northeastern.edu/csshresearch/bostonarearesearchinitiative/

For more information on this dataset, please refer to "A Guide to Using the Geographical Infrastructure of Boston (2015)":

http://dx.doi.org/10.7910/DVN/C5IULB
data.title: Intersections (Census) 2015, Boston (BARI)

data.name: Intersections (City), Boston
data.abstract:
Intersections comprise two data sets. One is a catalog of all intersections generated by the Census TIGER line roads data from 2013. The other is a master list of intersections maintained by the City of Boston that has then been merged with Census geographies (to the same intersection name when possible, otherwise to the closest point). This dataset is the latter: the city data. Variables are largely equivalent between the two files. The two data sets can be connected via their unique identifiers. They are split into two categories: identifying characteristics and geographic information. Identifying characteristics includes variables regarding the basic identity and attributes of the intersection. Geographic information provides further detail on the location of the intersection and the other geographies that contain it.

data.name: Roads, Boston
data.abstract:
This data set contains a complete list of all road segments in Boston, MA, as defined by Census TIGER Line data. It contains 24,891 segments. Roads variables are split into two categories: identifying characteristics and geographic information. Identifying characteristics includes variables regarding the basic identity and attributes of the address. Geographic information provides further detail on the location of the road and the other geographies that contain it. Because roads often form the borders between regions, nesting in higher levels was done using the road centroids.

Provided by the Boston Area Research Initiative (BARI)

https://www.northeastern.edu/csshresearch/bostonarearesearchinitiative/

For more information on this dataset, please refer to "A Guide to Using the Geographical Infrastructure of Boston (2015)":

http://dx.doi.org/10.7910/DVN/C5IULB
data.title: Roads 2015, Boston (BARI)

expected_format.description: Unique identifier used for the 45 million road segments in the U.S.
expected_format.name: Tiger Line Road Segment ID

expected_format.description: ZIP Codes are a system of postal codes used by the United States Postal Service (USPS) since 1963. The term ZIP is an acronym for Zone Improvement Plan.
